Lovelace pays the lowest out of all 3 major hospitals in Albuquerque. Most of their staff are now travelers. Forced overtime and canceled vacations were common. Facility is very old and in disrepair.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Albuquerque, NM
pros: You make some good friends in the office, if you’re lucky.
cons:
Please apply to UNM or Presbyterian. Lovelace does not care about you and will take advantage of you until you are gone. They knowingly have your covid positive co workers stay at your job without letting you know what is going on. They leave you extremely short staffed and expect you to pick up the slack as in having one person for a full clinic. The supervisors don’t step in to help when it’s busy other than saying “they’ll be with you in a minute” and not help diffuse angry patients. The clinical staff constantly berate the front desk and the CSC lead at I Square allows it to happen. They will come ask you rhetorical questions to make you feel stupid, but it’s because they want you to do one thing and supervisors tell you to do another so you’re stuck getting yelled at with no back up. 

Also, they have CSCs that constantly call out with no consequences so if you’re a decent worker that shows up to work then you’re stuck handling the whole day by yourself. The supervisors will make jokes about “maybe you should skip lunch next time, this is really hard for me! Haha” also they have severely unstable people working at Lovelace. I experienced CSCs having mental breakdowns that made me fear for my safety and they have these episodes in front of patients and it was brushed off by upper management. This person would scream and be aggressive while crying for minor issues and would be literally coddled by supervisors while us other co workers would be in fear for our safety. I have not had a good experience at any of their clinics and I’ve been to a lot of them. There are supervisors willing to trash talk you behind your back so that they can get a pat on the back without even speaking to you or letting you know there is an issue.

Holidays will come out of your PTO. 

You will be harassed to donate by Lovelace and they only match .50 for 1 etc. 

Management constantly texted me while I had COVID, didn’t even ask how I was doing just do you think you’ll be good to come in soon? 

You’ll constantly get berated by patients and get no help 

This whole place is a disaster with no expectations from patients or staff that leads to miscommunication and toxicity.

job_title: Customer Service Coordinator in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Growth opportunities, decent pay, good benefits, flexible schedule
cons: Long hours, schedule goes 24/7, management has its moments

pros:
The very top level of management is great. I think Lovelace is on the right track, they are trying hard to change things and how they run for the better. Benefits are excellent.

Each dept is different and luck of the draw. I worked 2 very different departments while I was there. One was good (inpatient), one not so good (outpatient). In my experience outpatient clinics aren't as busy, and are therefore breeding grounds for drama. My situation in the outpatient unit was unfortunate, as the "new" hire I tried desperately to fit into a well established clique. There were already 2 FT nurses, and as the third and newest hire guess who was the odd man out? My supervisor was spread very thin...she was over several departments. We could go days without seeing her, the only communication would be a daily morning text stating where she would be that day. She seemed disinterested in the goings on in our department and unaware of the problems. 

The dept that was good was an inpatient unit. It was crazy busy, however, the people I worked with were amazing, helpful, kind, and truly a team. A busy dept will be hard work...but the time will fly and most people are way too busy to sit around and gossip, play on their phones, and start trouble. 

In the interview process really take the time to interview them as well. Ask about their turnover rate, how they handle bullying, unfairness, etc. If you get a bad feeling, there's a reason for it! There is no hurry to accept or decline a position. Take your time and ask to interview many different departments and find people you feel good about who will treat you well. Look carefully at the employees that interview you. If they give each other side eye, roll their eyes, or patronize you during the interview you can guarantee that will carry over to your position as well. If you have a hard time during the first week of your job, ask for a transfer!! There are enough openings you can go where you will be happy and can find fulfillment. Don't try to stick it out for months hoping things will change. Put your own happiness and wellbeing first, because no one else will. 

HR is okay, just remember their job is ultimately to protect the company. So if things go south, you are on your own. 

Remember friends, there is a nursing shortage. Supply vs demand gives us the opportunity to improve our working environments. Best of luck to everyone!
cons: The comments as seen above.

review_title: I was an employee and now I am not, and will never be their employee again!
job_title: RN Critical Care in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Only pro I can think of is the pay scale.  Lovelace has one of the highest pay scales in Albuquerque.
cons: So many cons....employees are pushed and pushed beyond their limits!  Creating high stress, low employee retention and employee dissatisfaction.  Administrators say they care about patient safety, employee satisfaction, patient and family satisfaction but their actions say otherwise!  Patients express concern about their care and refuse to return.  Employees are fired, DNR'd ( do not return), or resigning.  Most departments have a very high employee turn over.  Nurses are expected to take on more and more responsibilities, nurse to patient ratios higher then the national standard setting the nurse up for failure and patient safety compromised.

pros: Get paid for the job hired to do, and benefits.
cons: Hostile work environment fostered and endorsed by management.  Management plays favorites with employees who are part of their "mutual admiration society."  Lazy middle and upper management who looks the other way when their "favorites" don't do their job or abuse other employees.  Managers who have been promoted over positions they know nothing about and are not able to audit their favorite supervisors/managers to make sure they are doing their jobs.   Truly one of the worst working experiences I've ever had.  Very unprofessional and shocking behavior.

review_title: Cheapest hospital around.  Concerned more with their bottom line than with providing the best health care possible.
pros: There really are not any positives. Despite being a hospital, the health care benefits are expensive without being particularly good.
cons: They do not appreciate training or experience, "cheating" on the lack of legislation by the state of New Mexico (other states made changes 40 years ago), which allows them to hire untrained, inexperienced individuals over those who are.  Lovelace hires poorly, pays poorly, charges more for benefits than competitors, and as a result of these, demonstrates their lack of concern over patient comfort and care as opposed to cutting corners and making a buck. If you are truly concerned about your patients, this may not be the environment for you.

review_title: Solid company with the right approach - but a bit too hyperactive.

Decent compensation, good benefits - company interested in hiring talent and paying what it takes to get it (a premium, in New Mexico).
cons: Tendency to be impulsive in high-level business management makes the company a bit inconsistent and frenetic.  Company might sell off your business line/unit.  In critical situations, company will ask a LOT of you - probably too much, but you won't mind as much as other places.
